summary: U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton took a message of free trade and open markets to Asia Saturday, saying Washington is "placing economics at the heart of our own foreign policy."

summary: Three weeks after superstorm Sandy, students whose families were displaced find themselves struggling to settle into an unfamiliar routine. Not only are they grappling with sudden homelessness, some are sitting among former classmates in a different building.

headline: Knicks Fans, You Are Not Dreaming
summary: There's definitely reason to be surprised by the Knicks' hot start. But the biggest surprise so far isn't how good the Knicks are, instead, it's how they got this good so quickly.

headline: Is Maya Cho in Love With Her Handsome Doctor?

summary: Hurricane Sandy buried this coastal town in six feet of sand.

summary: Erin McKean's field guide to unusual words in this week's Wall Street Journal includes kamnan, ophidiophobia and gull.

summary: Recent photography exhibitions of Neil Folberg and at the Korea Society.

summary: The immobilizing impact of Sandy has largely receded for millions of mass-transit riders across the region, leaving a miserable minority: motorists with ruined cars.

summary: On the agenda: Self-healing artificial skin, how sadness leads to shortsighted behavior, and the spray that keeps men from going astray.

headline: If Iran Gets the Bomb
summary: How would U.S. and Israeli strategists deal with a much riskier Middle East?

headline: Does Survival of the Sexiest Explain Civilization?
summary: Is sexual competition responsible for much of culture, innovation and battles over egalitarianism?

headline: This Job Is for the Birds

headline: Talks Bring Hope of Broad Budget Deal
summary: Obama and congressional leaders agreed to move quickly on negotiations to avert a year-end fiscal crisis that has put markets on edge.

headline: Wal-Mart Seeks to Head Off Worker Protests
summary: Wal-Mart Stores tried to head off worker protests at its stores over the Thanksgiving holiday by filing an unfair-labor-practice complaint against a union the company says is behind the protest plans.

headline: A Touch of Creole in the East Village
summary: Almost everything about Paul Gerard's Exchange Alley is a mix between New York and New Orleans. Its name is derived from a street in the French Quarter, while its menu is an eclectic mix of New York cuisine with Creole touches.

headline: Dish Made Bid for MetroPCS Before T-Mobile Deal
summary: Dish Network Chairman Charlie Ergen made a bid to acquire MetroPCS in August for about $4 billion, the latest sign that the executive has pursued serious steps to enter the wireless business.

headline: Two Missing in Gulf Fire
summary: Federal officials continued searching the darkened waters of the Gulf of Mexico for two workers missing after an explosion and fire early Friday on an oil-and-gas platform.

headline: Petraeus Raised Terror Link

headline: Stringer to Announce Bid for Comptroller
summary: Manhattan Borough President Scott Stringer plans to make public his decision to abandon his bid for mayor and run instead for comptroller next year, a move that will be a boost to mayoral hopeful Christine Quinn.

headline: Japan Tobacco Share Sale Delay
summary: The Japanese government is pushing back the sale of its stake in Japan Tobacco, citing weak stock-market conditions, an uncertain political situation and a sharp economic slowdown.

headline: U.S.-China Ties in Flux as Rosters Fill
summary: Relations between the two largest economic powers are still in flux as both countries fill out the roster of officials responsible for the international economy and as new, contentious issues arise.

headline: Iran Set to Double Nuclear Fuel Capability

headline: Fateful Timing in Veterans' Tragic Crash
summary: The Midland, Texas, police department confirmed the identity of the four fatal victims in Thursday's accident in which a train crashed into a parade float carrying wounded veterans.

headline: No More Needling People About Tattoos

headline: Accident Puts New Spotlight on Rail Safety

headline: Twinkie Maker Hostess to Close

summary: The challenge for fashion-show designer Thierry Dreyfus is to create a 12-minute theatrical event more memorable than the dozen or so other shows the audience will see that day.

summary: On the agenda: "Frida and Diego" in Toronto, a Tokyo survey in New York and local artists in Miami.

headline: Next Premier Came of Age in Era of Openness
summary: One key question surrounding China's leadership change is whether Li Keqiang, who was exposed to Western concepts as a student at Peking University, will encourage reforms.

headline: U.S. Closes Antitrust Investigation Into Seed Industry, Monsanto
summary: The Justice Department has closed a formal antitrust investigation into the U.S. seed industry, which is led by crop biotechnology giant Monsanto, without pursuing charges

headline: Applicants Rise for Immigration Program

headline: Cairo's Outreach Feeds Hopes in Gaza

summary: The government extended the deadline for states to decide whether to implement a key piece of President Barack Obama's health overhaul after Republican state officials struggled to reach decisions.

summary: For runners with Olympic aspirations, winning Saturday's NCAA cross country championship in Louisville, Ky., could be a launching pad.

headline: Dow's Gain Is Biggest Since Election

headline: The GOP's Inclusiveness Challenge

summary: An exceptional chronicle of one solider's experience during two years of World War II. Jonathan W. Jordan reviews Alex Kershaw's "The Liberator."

headline: Board Members Need  Lawsuit Protection
summary: Does Robert C. Pozen ("The SEC vs. J.P. Morgan," op-ed, Nov. 13) realistically expect corporate execs to expose their personal fortunes to the whims of agenda-, ideology- and publicity-driven politicians who can declare any company policy, at any time, corrupt and systemically harmful?

headline: A Violent Opposition To Other Religions
summary: Jon D. Levenson ends his article with a cautionary note concerning dialogue that falsely connotes the unity of the Abrahamic religions (Houses of Worship, Nov. 9, "Enlisting the Biblical Abraham as Peace Broker"

headline: Should Republicans Toss Some Principles Overboard?
summary: Sarah Westwood, in her "Advice From a Lonely College Republican" (op-ed, Nov. 12), insists the country is moving inexorably leftward on abortion and gay marriage, and she argues that the GOP must capitulate on these issues to win our generation.
